text: 2024 Statewide Directory of Family Violence Service Programs Serving Texas Families As the statewide membership coalition, the Texas Council on Family Violence (TCFV) represents family violence service providers, for-profit and non-profit agencies, government entities, and individuals dedicated to fulfilling our shared mission of building a safer Texas. Our membership reflects the vast diversity of Texas, with members providing a variety of community-based approaches to preventing and responding to family violence. As a membership-focused organization, TCFV serves as the unified voice before the Texas legislature on behalf of family violence survivors and service providers to support laws in the movement to end domestic violence. TCFV is firmly committed to serving its members, communities in Texas, and survivors and victims of family violence and their families. TCFV hosts an array of dynamic signature conferences, regional meetings, e-learning, and in-person training, throughout the year to support the capacity-building of member and non-member programs. Learn more about membership at www.tcfv.org/membership This directory is published by Texas Council on Family Violence and made possible by the Texas Health and Human Services Commission – Family Violence Program and the Texas Department of Criminal Justice – Community Justice Assistance Division. 4 Serving Texas Families This TCFV Statewide Service Directory includes family violence service providers, Battering Intervention and Prevention Programs (BIPPS), and community partners in Texas. Each listing will include the criteria for each respective agency. FAMILY VIOLENCE SERVICE PROVIDERS FVSP The family violence service providers listed in this directory are either TCFV organizational members and/or are funded by the Health and Human Services Commission (HHSC). In Texas, there are 97 family violence service providers, including TCFV’s 88-member programs. Family violence service providers offer an array of critical no-cost services to family violence survivors and their families, which may include: Crisis Services  24/7 emergency shelter and crisis line services  For more information, visit: www.tcfv.org/find-help/survivor-resources Legal Advocacy  Protective orders, other civil matter resources, and support in navigating local court systems  Legal counsel and referrals to pro bono or low-cost attorneys Support Groups and Counseling  Individual and group counseling sessions for survivors, children, and youth Advocacy Services  Safety planning and exploration of economic, legal, and housing options with trained advocates  Assistance navigating related systems such as Child Protective Services Transitional Housing  Free or reduced-rent apartment or rental units for 12-24 months, along with support- ive services to heal from trauma and secure permanent housing  For more information, visit: www.tcfv.org/housing-beyond-shelter HHSC-Funded Family Violence Service Providers: Comprehensive Services Of the 97 family violence service providers in Texas, 83 programs receive funding from HHSC (72 shelters, 7 nonresidential centers, and 4 standalone special nonresidential projects). These programs must provide comprehensive services to survivors, as outlined in the Texas Administrative Code (TAC), as well as follow a detailed survivor-centered set of regulations. HH SC For more information about these regulations, visit the TAC website by scanning this QR code: BATTERING INTERVENTION & PREVENTION PROGRAMS (BIPPs) BIPP TCFV provides technical assistance, oversight, and training to accredited

and funded Battering Intervention and Prevention Programs (BIPPs). The BIPP providers listed in this directory are funded by the Texas Department of Criminal Justice Community Justice Assistance Division (TDCJ- CJAD) and/or are TCFV members. Texas law provides that a court may require certain individuals to attend and complete a BIPP which has been accredited under CCP Article 42.141. Courts who opt to order BIPP are required to refer to accredited programs. The program or profes- sional must comply with TDCJ-CJAD guidelines, including:  Complete 25 battering intervention training hours and 15 family violence training hours  Conduct Federal and State Criminal Background Checks  Provide at least 36 hours of group intervention, with a minimum of 18 weeks  Promote the safety of victims, and hold offenders accountable by directly challenging, educating, and addressing the attitudes, beliefs, and entitlements that contribute to their violent behavior BIPP providers utilize a curriculum based on an intervention model recognizing intimate partner abuse as resulting from choices where one person systematically uses tactics of coercive control and violence to maintain power and control over the other. In doing so, BIPPs place the responsibility for behavioral change upon each offender to foster non-violent behaviors in relationships. For more on the TDCJ-CJAD state guidelines and for more information about the TCDJ-CJAD-funded BIPPs, go to www.tcfv.org/program-resources/ bipp-facilitators Region 1 Region 2 Region 3 Region 4 Region 5 Region 6 Region 7 Region 8 Region 9 Region 1 Region 2 Region 3 Region 4 Region 5 Region 6 Region 7 Region 8 Region 9 Region 1 Region 2 Region 3 Region 4 Region 5 Region 6 Region 7 Region 8 Region 9 Region 1 Region 2 Region 3 Region 4 Region 5 Region 6 Region 7 Region 8 Region 9 COMMUNITY PARTNERS CP Community Partner members support the TCFV mission and include government entities, faith-based and educational institu- tions, and other organizations and businesses committed to ending family violence. Carter Kingwood Emilee Whitehurst Houston Staley Heatly Vernon To all of our members, thank you. Both our individual and organizational members play a crucial role in the work of TCFV. Our members are a strong, unified voice before state and federal legislatures who provide essential knowledge of what is needed in their communities and show widespread support for the movement. TEXAS COUNCIL ON FAMILY VIOLENCE PROMOTES SAFE AND HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS BY SUPPORTING SERVICE PROVIDERS, FACILITATING STRATEGIC PREVENTION EFFORTS, AND CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR FREEDOM FROM DOMESTIC VIOLENCE. P O B O X 1 6

3 8 6 5 | A U S T I N , T E X A S 7 8 7 1 6 | 8 8 8 . 4 5 0 . T C F V ( 8 2 3 8 ) | W W W . T C F V . O R G 💬 Trauma-Informed FAQ Set for the Chatbot Concierge (You can upload this as a separate text or PDF file to CustomGPT and/or integrate the answers into your system prompt.) 📍 “What kind of help can I get at a family violence program?” Family violence programs offer many types of support, usually for free, including: Emergency shelter 24/7 crisis hotlines Safety planning Legal advocacy (like help with protective orders) Counseling for survivors and their children Transitional housing Referrals to food, clothing, and other basic needs Not all programs offer the same services. If you tell me your county or city, I can help you find a program near you. 🧳 “Can I bring my kids with me to a shelter?” Yes. Most shelters are set up to welcome both survivors and their children. If you have specific needs, I can help you find a program that can support them. 🐾 “Can I bring my pet?” Some shelters allow pets or partner with animal shelters to keep pets safe. Let me know your location and I’ll check which programs might have pet accommodations. 🕯️ “I’m not ready to leave, but I want to stay safe. Can I still get help?” Absolutely. You don’t need to be ready to leave to get help. Many programs offer safety planning, support, and resources—even if you’re still in the relationship. You deserve safety and support no matter your situation. 📲 “I don’t want to call. Can I text someone for help?” Yes. Some programs have text lines you can use instead of calling. Let me know where you are, and I’ll help you find one that offers texting support. 👤 “Do I have to give my name or personal info to get help?” You can often get support and information without sharing your full name. Programs are designed to protect your privacy and safety. 🧾 “What’s BIPP? Do they help survivors too?” BIPP stands for Battering Intervention and Prevention Program. These are programs for people who have used violence in relationships and are court-ordered or volunteer to change their behavior. BIPPs are focused on holding people accountable and are not designed to support survivors. But I can help you find a survivor-centered program if that’s what you’re looking for. 🌐 “I’m undocumented. Can I still get help?” Yes. Immigration status does not affect your right to safety and support. Many programs serve undocumented survivors and may also connect you with immigration legal help. 🧾 “Is this confidential? Will anyone find out I’m talking to you?” Nothing you say here is stored or shared with programs unless you choose to contact them. If you call or visit a program, they will explain your

confidentiality rights. Many have strict policies to protect your safety and privacy. 🧠 “What happens when I go to a shelter?” Each shelter is a bit different, but here’s what often happens: You’ll talk to a trained advocate who will ask about your situation If space is available, you’ll be offered a safe place to stay You may have access to food, clothing, toiletries, and support services You’ll work with staff to plan for next steps—at your pace If you’d like, I can help you find a shelter near you. 💡 “What if there’s no space at the shelter?” If one program is full, they may help you find another nearby with space. Let me know your location and I’ll help you get started. 🚨 “I’m in immediate danger. What should I do?” If you’re in immediate danger, call 911. For safety planning, shelter, or other help, I can guide you to a local family violence program right away.
